xxl.cursors
Class Bresenham

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--xxl.cursors.Bresenham
public class Bresenham
extends Object
implements Iterator

Produces Integers according to Bresenham's algorithm.
This graphical algorithm computes the best solution, i.e. the best distribution of points in two dimensional space, for a straight line with the help of two given points. Therefore the differences dx and dy are determined.
The Bresenham-Iterator also uses these two parameters and returns Integer-Objects, namely the number of points at one distinct level concerning the straight line, by applying Bresenham's algorithm.

The implementation of the nextmethod shows the the point's distribution (the returned Integer-Object):
(first call to next: state = dx; number = dy;) 

 	int next = 0;

	if (state>0) {
		next = (state-1)/dy+1;
		state -= next*dy;
	}
	state += dx;
	number--;
	return new Integer(next);
Now, a bit more generalized:
The given value dx, a totality of objects, is symmetrically distributed to a number of consumers dy. The maximum difference allowed is 1.

Example usage: 


	Bresenham bresenham = new Bresenham(12, 4);
	while(bresenham.hasNext())
		System.out.print(bresenham.next() +"; ");
	System.out.flush();
A Bresenham-Object is generated with a totality of 12 objects (points; dx). These 12 points should be symmetrically distributed to 4 consumers (dy). If Bresenham-Iterator is completely consumed it returned four Integer-elements each with the same value, namely 3.

For a better understanding a simple graphical demonstration of the use cases' Bresenham distribution: 


 		         *** '
 		      ***    '  dy = 4
 		   ***       '
 		***          '
 		-------------
 		   dx = 12

Method Detail

hasNext

public boolean hasNext()
Returns true if the iteration has more elements.
(In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)
Specified by:
hasNext in interface Iterator
Returns:
true if the Bresenham-Iterator has more elements, i.e. number > 0.

next

public Object next()
            throws NoSuchElementException
Returns the next element in the iteration using Bresenham's algorithm. The implementation is as follows: (first call to next: state = dx; number = dy;) 

 	int next = 0;

		if (state>0) {
			next = (state-1)/dy+1;
			state -= next*dy;
		}
		state += dx;
		number--;
		return new Integer(next);
A symmectrically distribution is realized.
Specified by:
next in interface Iterator
Returns:
the next element in the iteration.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if the iteration has no more elements.

remove

public void remove()
            throws UnsupportedOperationException
This method is not supported by Bresenham-Iterators, therefore an UnsupportedOperationException is thrown.
Specified by:
remove in interface Iterator
Throws:
UnsupportedOperationException - if the remove operation is not supported by the Bresenham-Iterator.

The main method contains some examples to demonstrate the usage and the functionality of this class.
Parameters:
args - array of String arguments. It can be used to submit parameters when the main method is called.
